{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3104531,"name":"","username":"ie67","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/i/e8c25b/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-11-28T09:43:51.119Z","cooked":"

For the last few years, my team made large frame-like elevators, like this:
https://grabcad.com/library/frc-elevator-mechanism-1

We‚Äôre noticing that the best teams are instead using telescopic arms, which require much less space. How does the routing work for those (for the strings, or whatever mechanism they use to extend the arms)? I know how continuous and cascading elevators work, but I don‚Äôt know how they condense it so much. Does anyone have a diagram of how that works?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-11-28T09:44:59.020Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4020,"reads":767,"readers_count":766,"score":20263.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":418764,"topic_slug":"routing-of-telescopic-arms","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://grabcad.com/library/frc-elevator-mechanism-1","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":621}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51188,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"TheFalcons"},"post_url":"/t/routing-of-telescopic-arms/418764/1","custom_user_title":"TheFalcons","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3104534,"name":"jedgar6","username":"jedgar6","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jedgar6/{size}/200602_2.png","created_at":"2022-11-28T10:23:01.477Z","cooked":"

I was a little confused as to what you were asking. I think I narrowed it down to ‚ÄúHow do teams make telescoping arms/climbers?‚Äù It‚Äôs actually pretty simple (if you are going with cots).

Our team used the Thrifty telescoping tube kit. It consists of 2 side plates with bearings and constant force springs. Then you use nested 2"x2" aluminum tubing, 1.5"x1.5" aluminum tubing, and in our case 1"x1" aluminum tubing. Then the constant force springs are connected to the bottom of the next inner stage (shown below).

cad.onshape.com

Onshape

Sign in to Onshape, the #1 fastest growing CAD system in the world with over 3 million users.

image229√ó798 32.2 KB

The point of the constant force spring is to pull up on each stage and extending the arms. If let go while compressed the arms spring up pretty quick.

Then you just tie a rope or cable to the top hook and run it down the center of each tube to a winch or shaft. Then you let the rope out and the arms extend and vice versa.

That‚Äôs how our team did it. There are several different ways out there to accomplish the same thing.

Is the question more about how to actively power in both directions? I think 3847 had a telescoping mechanism in 2018 with motors & chain. Search for their CAD library maybe

chrisrin:

actively power in both directions

Most teams with telescoping arms don‚Äôt actively power in both directions. They use springs to raise it and a winch to pull it down. Whiles it‚Äôs possible to power in both directions, its not nearly as easy, especially when you consider all the COTS solutions available.

Agreed. If the established spring-out / winch-in telescoping mechanisms work for your need, they‚Äôre probably the way to go. If not (e.g. if you need a manipulator on the extending end that is too heavy for the spring to lift), then the solution will be custom & more complicated.

chrisrin:

I think 3847 had a telescoping mechanism in 2018 with motors & chain.

They definitely did - 3946 and 3039b allied with them at Red Stick Rumble. They spent most of the time between matches trying to whack that thing straight enough to keep it from binding. The Pink Team (233) is well known for arms which extend, rotate, and have a manipulator on them; check their site for designs as well.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-11-28T21:12:15.213Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":51,"reads":554,"readers_count":553,"score":400.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":418764,"topic_slug":"routing-of-telescopic-arms","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/routing-of-telescopic-arms/418764/7","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3104911,"name":"Nathan Nguyen","username":"Potttaaatttooo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/potttaaatttooo/{size}/189101_2.png","created_at":"2022-11-29T04:04:33.982Z","cooked":"

Hello. If you are asking as to how COTS telescoping arms work (as seen in 2020-2022 for climbing), I am able to give you an explanation. If you are looking for how a telescoping arm works that is powered in both directions I‚Äôd recommend checking the rest of the replies.

For COTS telsecoping mechanisms, such as AndyMark‚Äôs Climber in a Box, TTB Telescoping Tube, or WCP GreyT telescope, there are multiple stages made up of box tubing. (1x1, 1.5x1.5, 2x2, etc). Each piece of box tubing has plates that mount to the top of it that hold constant force springs, and each tubing is inside each other (1x1 inside 1.5x1.5, and the 1.5x1.5 inside 2x2).

The constant force springs from for example the 2x2 plates mount to the bottom of the 1.5x1.5 tubing, trying to lift it up and extend it. In order to retract the telescoping tubes, there is a motor and winch near the bottom that wraps and unwraps string to make it shorter and longer. The string is usually attached to some bolt near the top of the smallest stage to fully extend and retract the tubes. Usually the string and motor winch are inside the tubes.

image778√ó1147 47.1 KB

As for rigging, as I said before the strings and motor winch are usually inside the tube, but that makes it a lot harder to replace the string if needed. Some teams such as 2910 have opted to have the motor winch on the outside to make it easier to replace the string. Hope this helps!

image631√ó1031 76.4 KB

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":18,"updated_at":"2022-11-29T04:04:33.982Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":61,"reads":524,"readers_count":523,"score":449.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":418764,"topic_slug":"routing-of-telescopic-arms","display_username":"Nathan Telescope ‚Äì WestCoast Products","clicks":54},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/c/a/ca4479f10f4a82d08da7983496e9472dd9bf3fc7.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0},{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/4/b/4b7be39059165b5d7f7eb1298768eff408fa83b0.png","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":42969,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4079 Alumentor | REV Ion Enthusiast | WCP & TTB Enjoyer"},"post_url":"/t/routing-of-telescopic-arms/418764/8","custom_user_title":"4079 Alumentor | REV Ion Enthusiast | WCP & TTB Enjoyer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3105019,"name":"Shane Tipton","username":"Saturn_233","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/saturn_233/{size}/162471_2.png","created_at":"2022-11-29T06:42:48.615Z","cooked":"

The chain runs through the telescopic arm and kind of works like a cascade, there‚Äôs CF (constant force) springs that extend the arm whuch are in the middle of the arm while the chain is usually run through the side. This can usually be driven by 1 decently powerful motor on a Gearbox at the end of the arm to retract it. For wires cable carrier or energy chain is used and flush with the arm, functions the same as cable carrier on a CNC and just keeps everything nice and organized. The springs are usually mounted on tube clamps at the top of the largest tube, a 10-15lbs of force spring should work fine. The tubes have blocks inside them for bearings which help the stages slide. You can do 2-1.5-1" or like 3-2-1" but there are many more options for tube sizes. In the middle of the arm is a large sprocket for the pivot and then on the superstructure there‚Äôs just a gearbox with a large reduction so it has plenty of torque and just outputs to a smaller sprocket. Usually the end of the arm isn‚Äôt too heavy for most games so you shouldn‚Äôt really have to worry about anything if you have a 1" tube at the end of your stage. Lmk if you have any questions, 3847 has some pics of our robot from logo motion on their website somewhere iirc. Also it takes a bit of fancy machining and some good wire management to pull it off but it‚Äôs definently worth it depending on the game. The key to packaging it well is putting as much into the tube as you can, the chain inside isn‚Äôt necessary so you can just use CF springs and rope if you want. West Coast Products, AndyMark, and TheThriftyBot all sell pretty good COTS telescoping arms which are great for climbers and easily modifiable for a pink arm GreyT Telescope ‚Äì WestCoast Products. Why extend vertically when you can go diagonal? P.S. I can put an explanation of the powered extension version on our website probably later this week for ppl interested.

jedgar6:

The point of the constant force spring is to pull up on each stage and extending the arms. If let go while compressed the arms spring up pretty quick.

We found out if you let it shoot up freely you‚Äôll end up bending the 8-32 bolts that mount the constant force spring assembly on the 2x2 or 1.5x1.5 tube. That is with the thriftybot kit.

Just doing it a couple times can bend them but not a lot. Honestly you don‚Äôt even notice that they are bent until you go to take them out. We had a few failures of the original 3d printed block that goes in the bottom of the 1x1 and 1.5x1.5 tubing.

Do note that the use cases of a framed elevator and telescoping arms are very different. An elevator is usually much stiffer and can carry higher loads in both directions, while telescoping tubes are less stiff and usually can only support high load when retracting.

Depending on what you mean by telescoping arm, this is not always the case. The actively-powered telescoping arms used for lifting manipulators are usually quite capable when it comes to loads, and I suspect that the longer aspect ratio means they handle moment loads better than typical elevators before they start binding
